Keywords: Interface Blend Nano-silica Poly(lactic acid)
a b s t r a c t
This work studies the effect of the interfacial assembly of spherical nano-silica particles on the morphology, rheology and mechanical properties of heterophase poly(lactic acid), PLA, and poly(butylene adipate-co-terephthalate), PBAT, blends. Through a controlled mixing strategy, nano-silica particles could be assembled in a stable fashion at the PLA-PBAT interface. Rheological analysis indicates that the interfacial assembly of nano-silica significantly diminishes the relaxation of the dispersed PBAT phase and 3 wt.% of nano-silica particles shifts the co-continuity region to a lower PBAT volume fraction. At co-continuity, the assembly of nano-silica at the interface changes the rheological behaviour of the cocontinuous PLA/PBAT from a liquid-like to a gel-like behaviour. The interfacial assembly of nano-silica reduces the co-continuous phase size but maintains co-continuity. The results of thermal annealing indicate a remarkable stabilization effect of interfacially assembled nano-silica on the co-continuous morphology. A conceptual model is proposed to explain the observed effects of interfacially assembled nano-silica on the morphology which emphasizes the critical role of nano-silica content, the relaxation time of the dispersed phase and the migration time of nano-silica to the interface. The mechanical properties of the PLA/PBAT blends are clearly influenced by the observed shift in co-continuity in the presence of nano-silica. Most importantly, the mechanical properties of cocontinuous PLA/PBAT are very sensitive to annealing due to morphological coarsening. Interfacially assembled nano-silica has the effect of completely stabilizing the cocontinuous morphology without any diminishing of the mechanical properties. These results clearly indicate the significant potential of the interfacial assembly of nanoparticles as a promising strategy toward achieving polymer blends with highly robust and stable co-continuous morphologies.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The addition of solid inclusions to polymer blends is a promising method for achieving a balance between toughness and stiffness [1–3]. Moreover, with systems that display double and multiple percolation phenomena, the addition of conductive solid particles to polymer blends to produce a semi-conductive polymer nanocomposites has also received much attention [4,5]. Nanoparticles, in particular, have significant potential to improve the mechanical and/or electrical properties at much
utylene .1016/j.
lower particle contents due to their much higher specific surface area. The localization of nanoparticles is a key parameter in achieving property control in multiphase systems incorporating nanoparticles [1,2,6–9]. It has been shown that the localization of nanoparticles in a dispersed rubbery phase increases the dispersed phase size by increasing the viscosity and elasticity of the dispersed phase [3,10]. On the other hand, the selective localization of nanoparticles in the matrix phase in a polymer blend reduces the dispersed phase size and increases not only the modulus and strength but also the impact properties [2,11].
The assembly of nanoparticles [8,12,13] and polymeric droplets [14,15] at the interface of polymer blends have recently received particular attention. From a morphological viewpoint, the interfacial assembly of nanoparticles in a blend with matrix-dispersed phase morphology considerably reduces the dispersed phase size and stabilizes the morphology through the formation of a solid shell around the dispersed phase [12,16–18]. However, the stabilization effect depends strongly on the wettability of the particles and their positioning at the interface. Nagarkar and Velankar [19] showed that in a blend of polyethylene oxide (PEO) and polyisobutylene (PIB), clusters of the dispersed phase (PEO) droplets bridged by silica particles were formed when silica particles were situated on the matrix (PIB) side of the interface. In addition, it has been shown that the localization of nanoparticles at the interface enhances the interfacial interactions between polymeric phases in the melt state [12,20–23].
In the case of polymer blends with co-continuous morphology, the interfacial localization of nanoparticles refines the morphology [18] and prevents coarsening of the phases during annealing and further processing through an interface jamming mechanism [20,24]. The interfacial localization of conductive nanoparticles in co-continuous blends is also considered as a promising method for enhancing electrical conductivity at much lower nanoparticle contents through multiple percolation phenomenon [5].
Despite previous studies on the effect of the interfacial localization of nanoparticles on the morphology and electrical conductivity of polymer blends, the mechanical properties of polymer blends with nanoparticles localized at their interface have been poorly investigated. This can be attributed to the complexity of this subject, which requires complementary analysis of the morphology, rheology and mechanical properties of the studied systems. For instance, Bitinis et al. [25] studied the effect of interfacial localization of organoclay on the mechanical properties of a PLA/Natural rubber (NR) blend and found that, depending on the surface modification of the particles, the addition of organoclay can increase either the elongation at break or the modulus of the blend.
In a previous study [26], nano-silica particles could be stably localized at the interface of a poly(lactic acid), PLA, and poly (butylene adipate-co-terephthalate), PBAT, blend. The morphology and miscibility of this blend system was characterized in detail in another study [27]. Considering the significant potential of PLA/PBAT as a fully compostable high performance bioplastic blend [27–29], the aim of this paper is to study the effect of the interfacial localization of nano-silica particles on the morphology, rheology and mechanical properties of PLA/PBAT blends. To this aim, the effect of the interfacial localization of nano-silica particles on the morphology and rheology of PLA/PBAT blends will be studied in three different regions of the PBAT phase composition: (a) in a blend with a matrix-dispersed morphology, (b) in a composition close to the boundary of the co-continuity region and (c) in the co-continuity region. The mechanisms responsible for the observed effects will also be examined in detail. Finally, the effect of the interfacial localization of nano-particles on the mechanical properties of PLA/ PBAT blends will be evaluated.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: PLA 3001D (NatureWorks) and PBAT (Ecoflex FBX 7011) were purchased from Cargill and BASF, respectively. Spherical nano-silica particles (SEAHOSTAR KE-P10) with an average diameter of 100 nm were purchased from Nippon Shokubai, Japan. All the materials were dried under vacuum at 60 C overnight to minimize their moisture contents.

sections.heading: 2.2. Blend preparation
sections.text:
An internal batch mixer (Plasti-Corder DDR501, Brabender) with a total mixing chamber volume of 30 cm3 was used to prepare all samples. Mixing was carried out at 50 RPM and 180 C for 10 min under a nitrogen blanket. The average shear rate at the mixing conditions was estimated as 25 s 1 [30]. Two mixing strategies were used:
(Pr1) the addition of particles to a PLA/PBAT melt (one step process); (Pr2) premixing nano-silica particles with PLA followed by mixing with PBAT (two-step process).
After mixing, samples were frozen in ice-water to freeze-in their morphology. The blend samples will be referred as PLA/ PBAT(XX/YY) where XX and YY indicate the vol.% of PLA and PBAT respectively. To maintain the PBAT/nano-silica ratio in all samples, the wt.% of nano-silica particles added to blends was based on the weight of the PBAT phase.

sections.heading: 2.3. Quiescent annealing
sections.text: In order to study the effect of quiescent annealing, samples from the internal batch mixer were held for 1 h in a hot press at 180 C under a nitrogen atmosphere and were then cooled to room temperature.

sections.heading: 2.4. Atomic force microscopy (AFM)
sections.text: A cryo-microtome (Leica-Jung RM 2165) was used to cut the samples under liquid nitrogen. The morphologies of the samples were determined by tapping mode AFM in air. AFM tips (ACTA-W from AppNano) with a tip radius < 10 nmwere used in this study.

sections.heading: 2.5. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM)
sections.text: In order to determine the morphology and the localization of silica particles, samples were fractured in liquid nitrogen and the sample surface was coated with gold. The morphology was then observed with a Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FE-SEM, JSM 7600F, JEOL) working at an accelerating voltage of 5 kV and a working distance of 7 mm. All SEM images were captured using a LEI detector.

sections.heading: 2.6. Image analysis
sections.text: As shown in a previous paper [27], the dispersed phase in PLA/PBAT exists in the form of fibers. The average dispersed PBAT fiber size was determined using a commercial software (Sigmascan Pro. V.5, Sigmaplot) from an average number of 250 dispersed phase fibers from AFM images. In order to consider the effect of fiber alignment on the observed crosssection of PBAT fibers in microtomed samples, an approach presented in the previous study, based on measuring of the smallest diameter of the cross-section of PBAT fibers, was used [27]. The average dispersed fiber diameters are reported as XX ± YY where XX is the average value and YY represents the standard deviation. The normalized interfacial area in the co-continuous blends was determined based on the method presented by Galloway et al. [31]. In this way, the interface was mapped from AFM images using the image analysis software and then the normalized interface length (lm/lm2) was obtained by dividing the length of the interface to the area of the image.

sections.heading: 2.7. Rheological analysis
sections.text: All samples were compression moulded at 180 C and at 300 kPa in the form of 1.2 mm thick disks of 25 mm diameter under a nitrogen blanket. The rheological analysis was done using a controlled stress rheometer (Physica MCR 301, Anton Paar) with a 25 mm parallel plate geometry at a 1 mm gap and 180 C under nitrogen atmosphere. The time sweep tests indicate insignificant (<7%) drop in the complex viscosity and storage modulus of PLA and PBAT in the experimental time scale of 40 min. Moreover, strain sweep tests for the neat polymers and the polymer blend samples at different frequencies were carried out to determine the linear viscoelastic region. According to the obtained results, the frequency sweep tests for neat polymers and polymer blends were performed at strains of 5% and 1% respectively.

sections.heading: 2.8. Tensile properties
sections.text: Dog bone samples with dimensions corresponding to Type IV of ASTM D638 were prepared using compression moulding at 180 C and 300 kPa in a hot press under a nitrogen atmosphere. The samples were then cooled to room temperature using another press cooled with cold water. Samples were conditioned in an oven for a period of 40 h at 23 C and 50% relative humidity before testing. To study the effect of annealing on mechanical properties, the PLA/PBAT(50/50) blend and the blend with 3 wt.% of nano-silica were held in the hot press for 1 h and were then cooled to room temperature. Tensile tests were performed according to the ASTM D638 on an Instron 3365 tensile machine equipped with 5 kN load cell at a cross-head speed of 5 mm/min. An average and standard error based on 10 measurements are reported for each sample.

sections.heading: 2.9. Notched impact strength
sections.text:
Samples were prepared and conditioned as of the tensile test samples. The samples dimensions were 64 12 3.4 mm. A notch with an opening angle of 22.5 and depth of 2.5 mm was created in the samples using a notching machine (IMPACTKUT, TENSILEKUT ENGINEERING). The samples were conditioned at 23 C and 50% relative humidity for 40 h before testing. The tests were performed using an Izod impact pendulum (CEAST 6545) according to ASTM D256. The reported values are based on 10 measurements for each sample.

sections.heading: 3.1. Localization of nano-silica particles in PLA/PBAT blends
sections.text: In the previous study [26], the thermodynamic equilibrium localization of nano-silica particles in PLA/PBAT blends was determined to be in the PBAT phase. However, different localizations of nano-silica particles could be achieved by altering the mixing strategy. As can be seen in Fig. 1, when nano-silica is added to a melt of PLA/PBAT using mixing strategy Pr1, nano-silica particles are selectively localized into the PBAT phase while premixing of the particles with the PLA phase, using Pr2, results in the migration and stable assembly of nano-silica particles at the interface. The mechanism of the migration and localization of nano-silica particles was discussed in detail in the previous study [26]. Therefore, Pr2 will be used as the main mixing strategy to localize nano-silica particles at the PLA-PBAT interface throughout the rest of this paper.

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of interfacial assembly of nano-silica on the morphology and rheology of PLA/PBAT blends
3.2.1. PLA/PBAT blends with a matrix-dispersed phase morphology
sections.text:
In a previous study [27], it was shown that the dispersed phase in PLA/PBAT blends exists in the form of stable fibers due to the low interfacial tension of 0.6 mN/m between PLA and PBAT. As can be seen in Fig. 2, the interfacial localization of nanosilica does not change the fibrillar morphology of the dispersed phase. As the cryo-fracture occurs at the weakest points of the sample, parts of the fibers are located beneath the fracture surface which prevents presenting a statistically reliable aspect ratio for the PBAT fibers.
Fig. 3 shows AFM images demonstrating the effect of the localization of 3 wt.% of nano-silica on the dispersed PBAT fiber diameter of a PLA/PBAT(80/20) blend. Note that although the phases appear to be spherical they are actually cut-through fibers as shown in Fig. 2.
Image analysis results indicate that the interfacial localization of 3 wt.% of nano-silica reduces the volume average dispersed PBAT fiber diameter from 1.3 ± 0.2 lm to 0.8 ± 0.1 lm and narrows the dispersed fiber diameter size distribution. The decrease in the dispersed phase size by the interfacial localization of nanoparticles has been previously reported in the literature and is attributed to the decrease in the coalescence due to the solid shell of nanoparticles around the dispersed phase [8,11,17,21] and the reduced interfacial tension between phases in the presence of nanoparticles [21,22,32–34]. The interfacial interaction between polymer phases can be evaluated using the work of adhesion concept [35]. The work of adhesion (Wa) between the components in the melt state is shown in Table 1. These results point to a higher level of interactions between PLA/silica and PBAT/silica than between PLA and PBAT. Narrowing of the dispersed fiber diameter distribution, Fig. 3(d), can also be attributed to the enhanced interactions due to nano-silica assembly at the interface.
Previous studies in the literature [27,36,37] showed that rheological properties of PLA/PBAT blends can provide valuable information regarding the morphology of this system. Fig. 4 shows the effect of the interfacial assembly of nano-silica on the rheological properties of PLA/PBAT (80/20) blend.
The presence of a shoulder in G0 and an arc on the right side of the Cole-Cole plot of the neat blend are attributed to the relaxation of the dispersed phase [38] and are indications of a matrix-dispersed morphology in this sample. However, after the interfacial localization of 3 wt.% of nano-silica, both the shoulder in G0 and the droplet relaxation arc in the Cole-Cole plot disappear. As the localization of the particles does not change the matrix-dispersed morphology (Fig. 3(b)), these results indicate that the localization of 3 wt.% of nano-silica at the interface significantly diminishes the relaxation of the PBAT dispersed phase. sections.heading: 3.2.2. PLA/PBAT blend close to the co-continuity region
sections.text:
The onset of the co-continuity region in PLA/PBAT blends was determined previously to be located between 30 and 40 vol. % of PBAT [27]. In this study, the effect of the interfacial localization of nano-silica on the morphology of PLA/PBAT blends close to the co-continuity region was examined by preparing PLA/PBAT(70/30) with different nano-silica contents using Pr2. Figs. 5 and 6 show the morphology and rheological properties of these samples.
Both the morphology and the presence of a droplet relaxation arc in the Cole-Cole plot indicate a matrix-dispersed phase morphology in the PLA/PBAT (70/30) neat blend. Image analysis indicates that the interfacial localization of 1 wt.% of nanosilica reduces the volume average dispersed PBAT fiber diameter from 1.7 ± 0.25 lm to 1 ± 0.1 lm. As discussed in the previous section, this is attributed to the decrease in the coalescence in the presence of nano-silica at the interface. Interestingly, increasing nano-silica content to 3 wt.% changes the morphology to a highly continuous structure. The continuity level of the phases in a polymer blend is commonly examined by the selective extraction of either phase [42]; However, this method is not applicable in PLA/PBAT blends due to the very close solubility parameters of the polymers. Rheological analysis, however, can be a useful tool in this regard. Fig. 6 indicates that the interfacial localization of 1 wt.% of nano-silica shifts the relaxation of the dispersed PBAT phase toward lower frequencies (longer times), but the relaxation arc can still be clearly seen in the Cole-Cole plot which indicates a matrix-dispersed phase morphology in this sample. By increasing the nano-silica content to 3 wt.%, both the shoulder in G0 and the relaxation arc in the Cole-Cole plot disappear which is attributed to the hindrance effect of nano-silica on the relaxation and mobility of polymer chains close to the interface [21,39]. In addition, a plateau in G0 and an upturn in g⁄ are observed in the low frequency data which point to a transition to a gel-like behaviour. A similar transition to a gel-like behaviour has been reported in Pickering emulsions and polymer blends where droplet clustering occurs and was attributed to the formation of a network of solid particles between clustering droplets [19,43–46]. droplet clustering occurs when the particles are preferentially wetted by the continuous phase. However, no preferential wetting of nano-silica particles by the PLA phase is observed in this system (see Fig. 1(b)). In addition, the highly continuous structure in this sample, as observed by AFM in Fig. 5(c), clearly indicates that the observed gel-like behaviour cannot be attributed to droplet clustering. The observed gel-like behaviour is very similar to the rheological behaviour of bicontinuous interfacially jammed emulsion gels known as Bijels [47,48] where the gel-like behaviour is attributed to the formation of a 2D network of solid particles at the interface of the co-continuous emulsion. Therefore, it is likely to expect that in the sample with 3 wt.% of nano-silica, the formation of a 2D network of nano-silica at the interface limits the flow and deformation of the system and causes the observed gel-like behaviour. As the continuity of the interface is essential in this mechanism, the observed gel-like behaviour confirms the high level of continuity of the phases observed in the AFM images and indicates a shift in the co-continuity region by the localization of 3 wt.% of nano-silica. Filippone et al. [39] also reported a shift in the cocontinuous region of a HDPE/PEO blend by the interfacial localization of 1 wt.% of organoclay. They attributed this effect to an increase in the relaxation time of the dispersed phase in the presence of nanoparticles at the interface. This is in line with the observed slowing down of the relaxation of the PBAT phase by the interfacial localization of nano-silica, Fig. 6. However, the highly continuous structure is only observed when 3 wt.% of nano-silica is localized at the interface. Therefore, a minimum threshold of nano-silica content is required to alter the morphology and induce a co-continuous morphology in compositions close to the region of co-continuity.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Co-continuous PLA/PBAT blends
sections.text:
The effect of the interfacial localization of nano-silica particles on the morphology within the co-continuous region was examined by preparing PLA/PBAT(50/50) with 3 wt.% nano-silica using Pr2. The effect of nano-silica on the morphology of PLA/PBAT(50/50) is shown in Fig. 7.
The interfacial localization of nano-silica does not change the co-continuous morphology but the normalized interface length increases from 0.54 ± 0.08 lm 1 for the neat PLA/PBAT (50/50) blend to 0.7 ± 0.06 lm 1 which indicates a finer cocontinuous structure in the sample with nano-silica. Trifkovic et al. [20] also found that the localization of organoclay at the interface of a co-continuous LDPE/PEO blend results in a finer co-continuous structure and increases the interfacial area. They attributed this effect to the compatibilization effect of nano-particles. The effect of nano-silica on the rheological properties of the PLA/PBAT(50/50) blend is also shown in Fig. 8.
The rheological analysis of the neat blend does not show a relaxation of the dispersed phase which is a sign of a cocontinuous morphology in polymer blends [27,39]. However, the complex viscosity of the neat blend shows a liquid-like behaviour at low frequencies which indicates that the formation of a co-continuous morphology does not hinder the flow and deformation. Interestingly, when 3 wt.% of nano-silica particles is localized at the interface of this blend, a clear transition to a gel-like behaviour is observed in the rheological analysis. Thus, these results point to the formation of a network of nano-silica at the continuous PLA-PBAT interface in this sample as was also observed for the PLA/PBAT(70/30) blend with 3 wt.% of nano-silica.
Despite the interesting properties of co-continuous blends [42], their morphology is known to be sensitive to processing and post-processing conditions and typically show a significant phase coarsening upon annealing [49]. The effect of thermal annealing on the morphology of PLA/PBAT(50/50) and on the same blend with interfacially assembled nano-silica was studied and the results are shown in Fig. 9. The neat blend undergoes a significant coarsening which originates from the affinity of the system to reduce the interfacial energy through the reduction of the interfacial area between the phases. The coarsening in co-continuous polymer blends, such as PLA/PBAT(50/50), occurs through the flow of polymer melt from thinner sections to thicker sections in the co-continuous structure. When the thinner section is completely drained into the thicker section, it breaks up into small droplets. This mechanism results in the coarsening of the thicker sections and elimination of the thinner section in the co-continuous structure [50]. On the other hand, the morphology of the blend with interfacially assembled nano-silica is not significantly affected. This can be attributed to the interface jamming effect of nano-particles at

sections.heading: 3.3. Continuity development in PLA/PBAT blends with nano-silica localized at the interface
sections.text:
When nano-silica particles are localized at the interface of PLA/PBAT blends, the observed changes in co-continuous morphology development cannot be attributed to classic models relating the co-continuous composition and bulk rheology of the phases. A new semi-empirical mechanism explaining the observed effects of nano-silica on the continuity development in PLA/PBAT blends during mixing is thus proposed here. Fig. 10 shows different steps of this mechanism.
According to this mechanism, during mixing, a new PLA-PBAT interface is formed due to the deformation of the PBAT phase, the long relaxation and breakup time of the dispersed phase in the low interfacial tension PLA/PBAT blend [27,51] and the short migration time of nano-silica from PLA to the interface [26] allows nano-silica particles to migrate to the newly formed interface before the relaxation or breakup of the PBAT fiber. The migration of nano-silica stabilizes the newly formed interface and prevents relaxation or breakup of the PBAT phase. Repeating this mechanism produces a highly elongated fibrillar PBAT phase which promotes the formation of the co-continuous morphology in this system. The formation of more elongated PBAT phases can also be responsible for the smaller dispersed phase size in PLA/PBAT(80/20) and the finer cocontinuous micro-structure in the PLA/PBAT(50/50) blend. In addition to the dispersed phase relaxation time and the migration time of nanoparticles, nano-silica content is another important parameter in stabilizing the PBAT phase. sections.heading: 3.4. Mechanical properties of PLA/PBAT blends with nano-silica assembled at the interface
sections.text:
Figs. 11 and 12 and Table 2 show the mechanical properties of PLA/PBAT blends with nano-silica localized at the interface. The neat PLA shows a yield point with subsequent failure which is an indication of a brittle behaviour. However, all blend samples show a yield followed by necking and cold drawing which indicates that the addition of PBAT to PLA changes the mechanical behaviour from a brittle to a ductile behaviour. Blending PLA with 20 vol.% of PBAT increases the elongation at break by 29 times, but reduces the modulus and tensile strength. On the other hand, the impact strength increases by only 40% compared to the neat PLA. The insignificant increase in the impact properties of PLA by blending with low compositions of PBAT has been attributed to an in-sufficient interfacial adhesion between the phases in this system [28]. sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this work, the effect of the interfacial assembly of nano-silica particles on the morphology, rheology and mechanical properties of PLA/PBAT blends was studied. Morphological analysis indicates that the interfacial localization of nano-silica in a matrix-dispersed PLA/PBAT blend with 20 vol.% of PBAT reduces the dispersed phase size. The rheological analysis indicates that the interfacial localization of nano-silica significantly diminishes the relaxation of the dispersed phase in this system. A transition from a matrix-dispersed phase morphology to a highly co-continuous one was observed when 3 wt.% of nano-silica was localized at the interface of a blend with 30 vol.% of PBAT. In addition, rheological analysis indicates a transition from a liquid-like to a gel-like behaviour which was attributed to the formation of a 2D network of nano-silica at the continuous interface in this system. A conceptual model is proposed to explain the observed shift in the continuity development by the interfacial localization of nano-silica. According to this model, the migration and localization of nano-silica particles to the interface prevents the relaxation and breakup of the PBAT phase and leads to the formation of highly elongated dispersed PBAT phases. This enhances the continuity development in this system. The relaxation time of the dispersed phase, the time required for the migration of nano-silica to the interface and the nano-silica content are shown to be critical parameters in this mechanism. Within the PLA/PBAT co-continuity region, the interfacial assembly of nano-silica particles results in a finer co-continuous micro-structure. The effect of annealing on the morphology of co-continuous PLA/PBAT blends was studied and it was found that the localization of nano-silica at the interface significantly diminishes phase coarsening.
The interfacial assembly of nano-silica in PLA/PBAT does not significantly alter the mechanical properties of the system. However, a significant improvement in the mechanical properties was observed close to the co-continuous region where the interfacial localization of nano-silica changed the matrix-dispersed phase morphology to a co-continuous one.
The effect of annealing on the mechanical properties of co-continuous PLA/PBAT blends was also examined. Thermal annealing significantly reduced the mechanical toughness of co-continuous PLA/PBAT blends, but remarkably did not affect the properties of the blend with nano-silica localized at the interface. This is due to the stabilization of the co-continuous morphology by the interfacially assembled nano-silica which prevents coarsening of the phases during annealing.
Typically, co-continuous morphologies in polymer blends are known to be sensitive to thermal histories. The results from this work indicate the significant potential of the interfacial assembly of nano-particles as a strategy to stabilize the morphology and mechanical properties of co-continuous polymer blends. This provides a potential route toward the generation of robust co-continuous structures.

metadata.abstractText: This work studies the effect of the interfacial assembly of spherical nano-silica particles on the morphology, rheology and mechanical properties of heterophase poly(lactic acid), PLA, and poly(butylene adipate-co-terephthalate), PBAT, blends. Through a controlled mixing strategy, nano-silica particles could be assembled in a stable fashion at the PLA-PBAT interface. Rheological analysis indicates that the interfacial assembly of nano-silica significantly diminishes the relaxation of the dispersed PBAT phase and 3 wt.% of nano-silica particles shifts the co-continuity region to a lower PBAT volume fraction. At co-continuity, the assembly of nano-silica at the interface changes the rheological behaviour of the cocontinuous PLA/PBAT from a liquid-like to a gel-like behaviour. The interfacial assembly of nano-silica reduces the co-continuous phase size but maintains co-continuity. The results of thermal annealing indicate a remarkable stabilization effect of interfacially assembled nano-silica on the co-continuous morphology. A conceptual model is proposed to explain the observed effects of interfacially assembled nano-silica on the morphology which emphasizes the critical role of nano-silica content, the relaxation time of the dispersed phase and the migration time of nano-silica to the interface. The mechanical properties of the PLA/PBAT blends are clearly influenced by the observed shift in co-continuity in the presence of nano-silica. Most importantly, the mechanical properties of cocontinuous PLA/PBAT are very sensitive to annealing due to morphological coarsening. Interfacially assembled nano-silica has the effect of completely stabilizing the cocontinuous morphology without any diminishing of the mechanical properties. These results clearly indicate the significant potential of the interfacial assembly of nanoparticles as a promising strategy toward achieving polymer blends with highly robust and stable co-continuous morphologies. 2016 Elsevier Ltd.
